Award.AwardTitle: ExPert: dynamic analysis based fault location via Execution Perturbations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: ExPert: dynamic analysis based fault location via Execution Perturbations<br/><br/>Abstract<br/><br/>This project is studying dynamic characteristics of runs of faulty programs and<br/>designing promising dynamic analysis techniques to identify executed program<br/>statements where a fault lies, i.e. the fault candidate set. To narrow the set of<br/>statements in the fault candidate set, an array of automated dynamic analyses are<br/>being used in conjunction with each other. These analyses consider not only the<br/>failed run but also execution perturbations of this faulty run. The goal of this<br/>work is to focus the users attention on a small subset of statements in the<br/>fault candidate state. Identification of fault candidate set is based upon<br/>uncovering of two types of evidence: negative evidence and positive evidence. <br/>A negative evidence is considered as an indicator that leads to the conclusion <br/>that a value encountered during a failed program run is related to the program's <br/>failure. Positive evidence on the other hand indicates that some of the values <br/>computed during a failed run are in fact correct. Through a combination of negative<br/>and positive evidence we aim to produce a small fault candidate set. As part of <br/>this work we are identifying new sources of evidence. We are also carrying out a <br/>systematic integration of above dynamic analyses technology into a practical <br/>debugging environment.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE
